title: Bi-Weekly Food and Recipes Thread
selftext:
Foodies of r/India, tried out a new dish? Experimented with cooking yourself and lived to tell the story? Share here!

Feel free to share recipes, eating places, pictures, experiences etc.

**Food and Recipes Thread is posted every two weeks on Friday mornings |** [**Old Threads**](https://reddit.com/r/india/search?q=Bi-Weekly+Food+and+Recipes+Thread&restrict_sr=on&sort=new&t=all)

https://preview.redd.it/tti3fyiqw8n61.png?width=1487&format=png&auto=webp&v=enabled&s=7b05ed23b7e6dff392ae637a98524e812dfb4791
comments: I dont know how to cook. I need advice. How to begin ?
Start with something simple e.g. fried / boiled egg, daal / rice, potato subzi etc. Really depends on what you already know and preferences.
Do you know any Good sites  or channels that teach cooking well and are easy to understand? I don't like people who just say " swad anusar daale" for every ingredient.
I think Ranveer Brar's YouTube channel is the best right now https://www.youtube.com/chefranveer
Yeah. I do. Multiple times a week during winter. And not frequently during summer
I'd suggest starting out with making omelettes then. https://youtu.be/7dV4Qw8qdsA

Start by ordering Dal and Make Rice at home.
Then make jeera rice with some fried onions.
One you get the hang of the pressure cooker and a fry-pan, Try making some dal.

If you have the money, you can join some cooking diploma course which teaches on weekends. They are usually a bit expensive but they are fun and they teach so many recipes that you will become the best cook in your friend circle.
I know how to make that actually
Make maggi as well. But i ve never made pasta before. Next sunday or saturday for sure. Will give you an update on how it turned out for sure
